A copy of the given function with the specified
(a term from ECMAScript 2015) that wraps the original function object. Calling the bound function generally results in the execution of its wrapped function.
A bound function has the following internal properties:
The value that is always passed as
value when calling the wrapped function.
A list of values whose elements are used as the first arguments to any call to the wrapped function.
Executes code associated with this object. Invoked via a function call expression. The arguments to the internal method are a
value and a list containing the arguments passed to the function by a call expression.
When a bound function is called, it calls internal method
, followed by the arguments passed by the function call.
A bound function may also be constructed using the
operator. Doing so acts as though the target function had instead been constructed. The provided
value is ignored, while prepended arguments are provided to the emulated function.

A common mistake for new JavaScript programmers is to extract a method from an object, then to later call that function and expect it to use the original object as its
(e.g., by using the method in callback-based code).
Without special care, however, the original object is usually lost. Creating a bound function from the function, using the original object, neatly solves this problem:
is to make a function with pre-specified initial arguments.
These arguments (if any) follow the provided
value and are then inserted at the start of the arguments passed to the target function, followed by whatever arguments are passed bound function at the time it is called.

to the callback function, in order to maintain the instance.

Thus, presented below are two options for
The first one is much smaller and more performant, but does not work when using the

Generally, in most code it's very rare to see
